referred_to_by.content: [CONTEXT] According to the AMH: "This place was located on the east coast of India, under Tuticorin. Shortly after the Portuguese expelled the Dutch from the surrounding region known as Madura, a lodge and a warehouse were built here in 1645 to store products". [COORD] The GM 2:337 footnote locates this place at 8°35'N and 78°8'E (before WGS84), a slight difference compared to the AMH coordinates.

[CONTEXT] The place was mentioned in the context of local social unrests in the dessavonie Matara (southwestern Sri Lanka) in 1757-1758. [DISAMBIGUATION] In GM vol. 13, the editors associate Kahawatte with Kadawatu (Caduatte-corle), but the creators of this dataset think this is incorrect. Therefore this entry is not to be confused with Caduatte-corle. Neither should it be confused with 'Kahawatta' in central Sri Lanka (GeoNames ID 1242403). [COORD] [INFERENCE] These are not coordinates of Kahawatte but of Mulgirigala/Adamsberg, which has been selected as an inference for Kahawatte because multiple sources have located Kahawatte in proximity to Mulgirigala/Adamsberg.

[DISAMBIGUATION] Not to be confused with Chowghat/Chavakkad (GeoNames ID 12681977). According to a 19th-century gazetteer, this place (Chattwye/Chetwa/Chitwa) was located about three miles from Chowkaad/Chaugat. [COORD] [AUTOMATIC]

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned (GM 6:691) in relation to the Coromandel Coast, in particular to places such as Thanjavur and Nagapattinam. A 1720s map by François Valentijn located 'Tiruweloer' east of Thanjavur and west of Nagapattinam.

[CONTEXT] GM 4:118 mentioned an event in 1676 where the lands of Madurai were destroyed by the forces of Visiapour (Bijapur), Mysore, and "the Nayak of Ikeere." GM 4:148 mentioned "the Nayaks of Mysore and Iscere [i.e. Ikeere]" in relation to a ruler of Tanjore named Ekoji. [ASSOCIATION] The GM editors expressed uncertainty: GM 4:118 "Ikeere, perhaps Karur, place in the centre of South India [...]." Based on the context, it is more likely that 'Ikeere' is actually Ikkeri - located in present-day Karnataka, India - instead of Karur. Secondary sources such as Marcus Vink's mention Madurai, Tanjore, Mysore and Ikkeri in relation to each other.
[CONTEXT] GM 4:118 "[...] Karur, place in the centre of South India at nearly 11°N and 78°E."
[CONTEXT] GM 13:292 mentioned this place in relation to the Coromandel Coast, in particular to Thanjavur and the Pamani river.

[CONTEXT] The creators of this dataset have identified this place as Mandvi or Cutch-Mandvi, which - according to a secondary work by Kaveh Yazdani - was the chief port in the Gulf of Kachh/Kutch. According to the AMH, this place was a VOC post that fell under "the aegis of the headquarters at Suratte." [DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for (Cutch-)Mandvi. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the port town of (Cutch-)Mandvi and the VOC comptoir of (Cutch-)Mandvi.
[CONTEXT] GM 6:451 "Nilisaram, a kingdom in western India on the river of the same name on the border of Malabar and Canara at approximately 12° 18' N."

[DISAMBIGUATION] Two places with the same name 'Cottate' or 'Kottayam': 1/ One was a part of Tekkenkur, located more southerly in Tekkenkur (GM 4:203, 4:459). Tekkenkur or Thekkumkur was "an independent kingdom in Malabar, south of Berkenkur, at about 9°30'N" (GM 3:512). 2/ The other 'Cottate' was a small polity that "stood under the Kolattiri", located south of Cannanore or Kannur (GM 4:459). This entry refers to the first Cottate/Kottayam. [COORD] These coordinates correspond with a place named 'Kottete', south of Becciur, as seen in a 17th/18th-century map of southern India by Guillaume L'Isle and Bruzen la Martinière.

[CONTEXT] GM 5:848 mentions this place in relation to 'Wildoer' (Waltair or Visakhapatnam) and 'Bimilipatnam' (Bheemunipatnam) in India. According to a 19th-century gazetteer of the British East India Company, 'Konadah' was located in "the British district of Vizagapatam" at "lat. 18 °1' and long. 83°40'".
[CONTEXT] GM 1:291 "Kondavira, south west of Kistna, at 16°20'N and 80°15'E."
[CONTEXT] GM 2:713 "Punte de Pedro, Pedro Point; the northern tip of Ceylon."

[CONTEXT] GM 6:519 "Corretty, like Coddacherry, a kingdom in the interior under Cochin at about 10°N". [COORD] There are three GeoNames results for 'Koratti'; the result located closest to Cochin is selected.
[CONTEXT] GM 1:291 "Kondapilli, north of the Kistna at 16°40'N and 80°45'E."
[COORD] [AUTOMATIC]
[CONTEXT] GM 7:243 "Kolachol, place at 8° 15' N and 77° 12' E."
The footnote on GM 7:70 located Khana near Burdwan (present-day Bardhaman).

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in the GM (8:229, 11:407) in the context of some saltpeter contract with the English and the French, and in proximity to Patna (now a city in Bihar, eastern India). [COORD] There are multiple GeoNames results for 'Mau' in India. GeoNames ID 1263311 is selected because its location is similar to that of Mau identified in a secondary source by Murari Kumar Jha.

[DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Madurai in India. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the city of Madurai and the kingdom of Madurai. Not to be confused with the island Madura in Indonesia.

[CONTEXT] GM 3:28 "Mannagoyl, Manarkoil or Mannargudi, located at 10°42' N. and 79°25' E." [DISAMBIGUATION] Not to be confused with Mannarkovil in present-day Tirunelveli district (GeoNames ID 11655417).
[CONTEXT] GM 14:833 "Hulfsdorp, a neighborhood just outside the fort in Colombo, where the land council and the dessave were located, probably corrupted to Hulstdorf."

[CONTEXT] GM 6:593 "Marua, region on the southeast coast of India at about 9.5 to 10° N and 78.5 to 79° E, the area of ​​the Teuver." The word 'Marua' is a Dutch corruption of 'Maravar'/'Marava', which is a caste name, while 'Teuver' is a Dutch corruption of 'Thevar'/'Tevar', which, according to Marcus Vink, is a title often used by the Maravas. According to GM 3:509, the domain of the Thevar was located "in the south-eastern corner of India, just opposite the narrowest part of the Strait of Manaar, including also a part of the islands therein." [COORD] Coordinates derived from GM 6:593 (before WGS 84).

[CONTEXT] GM 4:202 "Maprana, a place in the north of Cochin, at almost 10° N, whose court stood under the Sammorine." GM 7:309 locates Maprana "north of Paponetti." Paponetti or Pappinivattam was a territory in what is today Kerala, India. [DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Maprana. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the fief of Maprana and the fort of Maprana.

[CONTEXT] GM 14:104-105 "[...] the three places located in the district of Goentoer and below it, named Moeta Pilly, Naayidy Pilly and Santarraroer"; GM 14:254 also mentioned the place in relation to Golconda. It is possible Muttupilly and Motupalli are the same place, although they feature as two different entries in GM 14 index. [COORD] Coordinates assigned based on the assumption that Muttupilly is the same as Motupalle (GeoNames ID 10789173).
[COORD] [AUTOMATIC]

[CONTEXT] GM 11:279 mentioned this place in relation to Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) and referred to it as one of the provinces of Manaar (island or gulf in northwestern Sri Lanka), along with Mantotte and Nanatan. [COORD] The GeoNames coordinates of the present-day Musali Division are used here, whose location resembles that of 'Moessellie' on 18th-century maps of Sri Lanka.

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in the GM (12:241, 14:254) in relation to the Coromandel coast, in particular to places such as Ramayapatnam, Carrera, and Mazulipatnam. [COORD] There are 3 GeoNames results for 'Motupalle'. GeoNames ID 10789173 is selected because it is located on the coast, which matches GM 12:243 description of this place as a "zeeplaats" and also matches the location of 'Montepoli' as seen on a 17th/18th-century map of southern India.
[CONTEXT] GM 3:303 "[...] the city of Monghyr on the Ganges at 86°30' E., which, however, is clearly mentioned further on as Mongeer."

[CONTEXT] GM 11:739-740 mentioned this place in relation to pearls in Ceylon (Sri Lanka): "the divers had not been able to find one of the banks, called the Modregamse." The location of this bank is illustrated by Figure 4 of a secondary source by Jinadasa Katupotha.
[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in the GM (14:262) in relation to Ceylon (Sri Lanka).
[COORD] GeoNames does not contain an ID for the fort, so the ID for Hanwella as a whole is taken. [AUTOMATIC]

[DISAMBIGUATION] The GM editors associated Nanjenadoe with Nanjangud, which this dataset's creators think is an error. The creators of this dataset believe that Nanjenadoe is actually Nanjanad, which is located in Kanyakumari district in present-day Tamil Nadu, India, and was formerly part of the princely state of Travancore - according a source by C. Hayavadana Rao.

[CONTEXT] GM 1:339 "Narsapur is located two-thirds of a degree east-northeast of Masulipatam." [DISAMBIGUATION] There are several different places with the name Narsapur/Narasapur in India. This entry concerns the Narsapur/Narasapur that is located on the Coromandel Coast.

[CONTEXT] GM 6:130 locates this place "on the Coromandel Coast, just north of Negapatam." The GM 6:695 text located this place "under Tansjauwer [i.e. Thanjavur]", and according to the footnote on the same page: "Naur, place on the eastern coast of India at 10°47'N." [COORD] [AUTOMATIC]

[CONTEXT] GM 11:178 "a landschap Nanjenadoe, which the Trevancore princes previously obtained from the Madurese empire as a fief". [DISAMBIGUATION] The GM editors associated Nanjenadoe with Nanjangud, which this dataset's creator think is an error. The creators of this dataset believe that Nanjenadoe is actually Nanjanad, which is located in Kanyakumari district in present-day Tamil Nadu, India, and was formerly part of the princely state of Travancore - according a source by C. Hayavadana Rao.

[CONTEXT] GM 12:155 mentioned this place in relation to Mahé and Cannanore, both located on the Malabar Coast. [COORD] GeoNames coordinates of a present-day populated place named Muttungal are used here. There is also a GeoNames ID (10924885) for a port named Muttungal, with closely similar coordinates.

[CONTEXT] GM 4:737 "Peritalli, kingdom in the interior of Malabar, behind Attingal, about 8°35' N and 77°8' E." A secondary work by M. O. Koshy confirms that Peritally was an alternative label for Nedumangad.

[CONTEXT] GM 5:141 located this place "in the interior [of India] about latitude 10°50' N. and longitude 76°42' E." [DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Palghat. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the city of Palghat and the kingdom of Palghat.
[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned (GM 3:222, 13:315, 13:598) in relation to Surat and Mumbai (Bombay), and other places in western India such as Rajapur and Khandala.
[CONTEXT] GM 3:805 "Uva, place located in eastern central Ceylon at 7°8' N and 81°5 E."
[COORD] [AUTOMATIC]

[CONTEXT] GM 11:61 mentioned this place in relation to several places/areas in eastern India - such as Bengal, Bihar, Orissa, Patna, and Kasimbazar - and in the context of the Maratha expeditions in Bengal (mid-18th century). [COORD] GeoNames coordinates of the Panchet Hill (West Bengal, India) are used here. There is also a GeoNames result for a ruined fort at this town, called Garh Panchkot (GeoNames ID 1271540).

[CONTEXT] GM 6:499 "Pesa or Peza, taken from the Portuguese Pesse, name for a place properly called Panderaturty, situated on the coast of Malabar at 9°N.; the V.O.C. had a pepper warehouse there." According to M. O. Koshy, "Peza was located on the south of Maruthurkulangara" and was called 'panderatoutte' by locals. [COORD] The GeoNames coordinates of a present-day locality named 'Pānduraturuttum Tura' are used here, whose location is roughly similar to that of Peza/Pantartoertij as seen on 18th-century maps of the Malabar Coast.

[CONTEXT] GM 14:119 "Pappinivattam is called Paponetty in the text." The entry for Pappinivattam in GM 14 index also stated: "Pappinivattam (ook: Paponettij, Paponetty)" - which indicates that Pappinivattam and Paponetty are the same place. GM 7:224 "Paponetty, stretch in Malabar, just inland at 10° 14' N."

[CONTEXT] GM 2:448 "Cassuri, Cajurim, also called Hinsele, an island in the Ganges delta, which was ceded to the Portuguese by Musundulim and which is apparently governed by a priest." According to a secondary source by H. Hosten, "Angelim (Hijlī) was the centre of an extensive salt industry, and a fort presumably stood on Cajurim island. Hijlī has long been submerged in the sea." [COORD] [INFERENCE] According to H. Hosten, a fort was located on the Cajurim/Hijli island, so the island's location is used here as an inference for the fort. Regarding the island's location: the GeoNames coordinates of the Hijili Flat (tidal flat) are used, for its location seems to match that of Hijili/Angelim as identified by maps in a secondary work by H. Hosten and a primary source by Olfert Dapper.
[CONTEXT] GM 2:712 "[...] the island of Rameswaram, an end of the connection between India and Ceylon, which we know as Adam's Bridge."

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in the GM (GM 12:566, 14:824) in relation to Palakollu, Penukonda, and Machilipatnam. GM 12:566 "[...] Pettapour, located under the dominions of Prince Timmeragie" (GM 6:249 assumed "prince Timmeragie" meant "Timu Radja").

[CONTEXT] The GM text (GM 10:222, 13:82) mentioned this place in relation to places on the Malabar Coast, such as Cochin, Madalagam, Paponette, and Chettua. Based on a 1767 map by Joh. Wilh. de Graaf, this place was located in what is today Chettuva, on the bank of the Karuvannur river. [COORD] Around the location of Poelicarro as seen on a 1767 map by Joh. Wilh. de Graaf, in present-day Google Map there are some places with names that seem similar, such as the Pulikkakadavu Bridge and the Chettuwa-Pulikkakadavu Road. The coordinates of the Pulikkakadavu Bridge are selected here.
[COORD] [AUTOMATIC]

[CONTEXT] GM 13:411 mentioned this place as a weaving centre or textile-producing place, in relation to several other places in what is today West Bengal, such as Santipur, Chandrakona, Haripal, Dhaniakhali. According to Om Prakash, "Radhanagar was about an hour’s distance in the south-southeast of Khirpai."

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in relation to the Bengal region, in particular to Bihar, Patna, and Bhagalpur (GM 11:794, 12:334, 12:504) [COORD] There are many GeoNames results for Puraini in India. It is uncertain which is the most exact result, so based on the context, the first GeoNames entry for Puraini in Bihar has been selected.

[CONTEXT] According to a 1751 map by Baltus Jacobsz. van Lier, the 'Raygam Corla' was located on the western coast of Sri Lanka, south of Colombo. [COORD] [INFERENCE] The GeoNames coordinates of Pinwatta are used here as an inference for the Raigam Korala because several 17th/18th-century maps of Sri Lanka locate Pinwatta in the territory of the Raigam Korala.

[CONTEXT] GM 11:180, 11:298 mentioned this place in relation to the Malabar Coast, namely to places such as Cochin, Koratti, Cranganore. According to the Indian government website, Punnathur Kotta (i.e. Punnathur fort) "was once the palace of a local ruler, but the palace grounds are now used to house the elephants belonging to the Guruvayoor temple, and has been renamed Anakkotta (meaning “Elephant Fort”)." [COORD] [INFERENCE] Based on the context (see Overall Remarks), the GeoNames coordinates of Guruvayur are used here as an inference for Punnathur.

[CONTEXT] According to the AMH, "Edappalli, also called Ellengallur or Repolim, was the site of a small kingdom. This principality owned estates spread all over Malabar." Additionally, GM 4:460 located this kingdom to the north of "Anjikaimal or Curumadu, kingdom east of Cochin." [COORD] Coordinates of a present-day populated place named Edapalli are used here, whose location is roughly similar to that of the Repolim kingdom in the 17th/18th centuries, as seen on a map provided by M.O. Koshy.

[CONTEXT] GM 3:511 "Porca, actually Purakkad, kingdom of the Malabar Coast with an important city at 9°20' N." [DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Pirakkad. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the kingdom of Pirakkad and the VOC residentie of Pirakkad. Not to be confused with another place also named Purakkad but located north of Kozhikode/Calicut (GeoNames ID 10926331).

[CONTEXT] According to M. O. Koshy, Quilon de Sima is the same as Tangasseri. In addition, GM 12:472 mentioned "[...] the palace of the expelled king of Signattij, standing in the district of Coilan de Sima" - according to GM 4:737, "Signatty appears by the VOC as the name of a kingdom on the coast of Malabar at about 8°50' N, with Coylan or Quilon as its main town."

[CONTEXT] GM 14:729 located Ramgarh at "opposite Benares" (Benares is the present-day Vanarasi in Uttar Pradesh, India). GM 11:61 also mentioned this place in relation to Benares as well as several places/areas in northwestern India - such as Patna, Bengal, Bihar, Orissa - and in the context of the Maratha expeditions in Bengal (mid-18th century). [COORD] There are multiple results for 'Ramgarh' on GeoNames. GeoNames ID 1258682 is selected based on the information provided on GM 14:729, which locates Ramgarh opposite Benares/Vanarasi.

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned as a village in relation to Tanjore/Thanjavur (GM 12:344, 12:456), along with another village named Chikel/Chikil. [DISAMBIGUATION] Not to be confused with another village in the same area called 'Paleoer'/Palkur. [COORD] The place name 'Poeleoer' might be a Dutch corruption of 'Puliyur'. There are, however, multiple places in India named Puliyur. Here, based on the context (see Overall Remarks), the GeoNames result for 'Puliyur' located the closest to Thanjavur has been selected.

[CONTEXT] GM 2:764 located Saffragam or Sabaragamuwa far inland around the river Kalutara [Kalu Ganga] of Sri Lanka. [COORD] GeoNames coordinates of the present-day Sabaragamuwa Province are used here, whose location is roughly similar to that of the Saffragam korale/dessavony administered by the Dutch in the 17th-18th centuries, as seen on a 1672 map of Sri Lanka, but the borders of the modern province are likely different from those of the korale/dessavony.
[CONTEXT] GM 6:35 "[...] Shevaroy, a mountain area in South India at approximately 11°40' N and more than 78° E."
[CONTEXT] GM 3:432 "Chicacole, former capital ["hoofdstad"] of Orissa, at about 18° N and 84° E."
[CONTEXT] 17th/18th-century maps of Sri Lanka located this place south of Mantota, on the northwestern coast of Sri Lanka.

[CONTEXT] GM 5:767 mentioned a seminary "established in the V.O.C garden ['tuin'] Nalloor, an hour's walk outside Jafnapatam." [DISAMBIGUATION] This entry refers to Nallur in present-day Maruthady, Jaffna, Sri Lanka. Not to be confused with many places named Nallur in India.

[CONTEXT] GM 1:392 - "Sitavake, place in the interior of Ceylon, east of Colombo, at 7° N and 80°15' E." According to the Encyclopedia of Sri Lanka by Charles A. Gunawardena, nearby the present-day town of Avissawella are "the ruins of Sitawaka, capital of a 16th-century kingdom that fiercely resisted the Portuguese [...]." [COORD] [INFERENCE] The coordinates of the city Sitawaka are used here as an inference for the location of the kingdom of the same name, because according to Gunawardena, the former was the capital of the latter. There are several GeoNames entries which this place can be linked to: (1) Seethawaka, ID 11983755, an administrative division in modern Sri Lanka; (2) Avissawella, ID 1250720, the present-day town at which the ruins of Sitawaka are located (the AMH even used Avissawella as the preferred label for Sitawaka); and (3) the ruins Sitawaka, ID 1227862, whose coordinates are closely similar to the two entries above. This dataset's creators have decided to link this place to the GeoNames ID of the Sitawaka ruins, as it seems closest to the historical period of the VOC.

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned (GM 12:52, 12:245) in relation to Sri Lanka, in particular to Trinconomale [i.e. Trincomalee] and Koddiyar. [DISAMBIGUATION] Not to be confused with Tampakamam in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka (amh_825p; GeoNames ID 1227068).
[CONTEXT] GM 12:142 located this place "south of Arcadoe" (Arcot, in present-day Tamil Nadu, India).

[CONTEXT] 18th-century maps of the Malabar Coast show that there were three places labeled as 'Aijwika' or 'Aijwike': a VOC wacht post at Groot Aijwika/Aijwieke; a 'pagood' at Cheria Aijwika/Tjerri Aijwike; and a church (kerk) at Kleijn Aijwike. It is unclear which of these places the GM was referring to. All three of them were located on a narrow strip of land located to the south of Calicoilan (present-day Kayamkulam) and to the north of Coilan (present-day Kollam) - based on Google Maps this land strip is present-day Alappad. [COORD] [INFERENCE] The GeoNames coordinates of Kuzhithura are used here as an inference because Kuzhithura is located in the middle of the land strip on which the three places named Aywika were located (see Overall Remarks).

[CONTEXT] GM 13:185 mentioned this place in relation to places on the Malabar Coast, such as Cochin, Travancore and Enamakkal. According to Ji Vēṇu, Trippunithura is located in the present day Ernakulam district in Kerala, India. (GeoNames ID for Ernakulam: 1272019)

[CONTEXT] GM 4:636 "Tellichery, town on the coast of Malabar at 11°43' N., where the English established their first permanent settlement on this coast in 1683, the French had an establishment there in the 70s."

[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned (GM 10:354, 11:627) in relation to the Coromandel Coast, in particular to places such as the Tondi bay, Karaikal, and Kulasekharapatnam. According to Corpus Diplomaticum volume 3, Adrampatnam was another name for Adrangapatnam. [COORD] GeoNames coordinates for the present-day municipality of Adirampattinam are selected here, whose location is similar to the location of 'Adriampatam' on a 1720s map of southern India by Francois Valentijn.

[CONTEXT] The DSSA mentioned this place in relation to places on the east coast of Sri Lanka, such as Batticaloa, Kottiyar and Trincomalee. It is likely that this is the same place as 'Panoa' mentioned on GM 3:506 - "Panoa, district on the east coast of Ceylon south of Batikalao [i.e. Batticaloa]."
[CONTEXT] GM 3:96 "Caljemeer, Calimere, the cape where the east coast of India joins the southeast coast, at 10°20' N and 79°50' E."
[CONTEXT] GM 7:183 "Alendele, island on the south coast of Madura". [COORD] Coordinates derived from GM 7:183 footnote (before WGS 84).

[DISAMBIGUATION] The GM editors regard Vadakku Valliyur as the same place as 'Waddacoedi'. The latter was a village under Nagapattinam, most likely named Vadakkudi in the present. The researchers of this dataset have not found any source apart from the GM that indicates 'Waddacoedi'/'Vadakkudi' as another name for Vadakku Valliyur or vice versa. We think that Vadakku Valliyur is actually the name of a village in Tirunelveli, instead of in Nagapattinam. Hence, Vadakku Valliyur in this dataset is treated as a separate entry from Vadakkudi.

[CONTEXT] A VOC document referred to this place as "het onder Nagapatnam gehorende dorp Wade Coedie" (the village Wade Coedie, belonging under Nagapatnam). [DISAMBIGUATION] The GM editors regard 'Waddacoedi' as the same place as Vadakku Valliyur. However, the researchers of this dataset have not found any source apart from the GM that indicates 'Waddacoedi'/'Vadakkudi' as another name for Vadakku Valliyur or vice versa. We think that Vadakku Valliyur is actually the name of a village in Tirunelveli, instead of in Nagapattinam. Hence, Vadakku Valliyur in this dataset is treated as a separate entry from Vadakkudi. [COORD] There are several GeoNames result for 'Vadakkudi'. Based on the context (see Overall remarks), the entry most connected to Nagapattinam is selected.

[CONTEXT] GM 4:227 "Travancore, one of the southernmost kingdoms of Malabar, emerged since 1729 and then became one of the most important, expanding strongly towards the north." [COORD] [INFERENCE] The coordinates of Thiruvananthapuram (the capital city of the present-day Indian state of Kerala) are used here as an inference for the location of Travancore. According to Tara Boland-Crewe and David Lea, in the mid-18th century, Thiruvananthapuram became the capital of the kingdom of Travancore (before 1750, its capital was Padmanabhapuram).

[CONTEXT] GM 3:564 "Baliapatnam, Valarpattanam or Azhikkal, place on the west coast of India, near the Monte Delly mentioned on dl. II, p. 205, located at about 12° N." (GM 2:205 "Monte Delly, the approximately 280-meter high mountain on the west coast of India, at over 12° N., where Vasco da Gama first saw this country in 1498.")
[CONTEXT] GM 4:148 "Udaiyarpalaiyam, place at 11°6' N and 79°20' E."
[CONTEXT] This place was mentioned in relation to the Malabar Coast and to Christian bishop, in particular Carmelite bishop (GM 10:923, 12:63).

[CONTEXT] GM 6:447 "Walallawiti-korale, district in Southwest Ceylon at 6°30' N and 80°20' E." According to 18th-century maps, this korale was bordered to the north by the Pasdum korale, to the south by the Galle korale, and to the west by the sea. [COORD] GeoNames coordinates of a present-day populated place named Walallawita are used here. The location is roughly similar to that of the 18th-century korale of the same name, as seen on maps of this period.

[CONTEXT] GM 13:175-176 and 14:818 mentioned this place in relation to Bobbili and Visakhapatnam (both located in present-day Andhra Pradesh). [DISAMBIGUATION] Not to be confused with Vijayanagar(a) in Karnataka.
[CONTEXT] GM 1:624 "Wierwasserom, Virvasaram, place in the Kistna district at 16°32' N. and 81°37' E., where there was an English office until 1702."
[CONTEXT] GM 2:347 "Wandiwash, Vandivasu, fortified place at 12°30' N and 79°35' E."

[CONTEXT] GM 6:721 "Muliawalle, coastal area on the north of the east coast of Ceylon at 9°18' N." [COORD] There are GeoNames results for several present-day administrative divisions that contain the label 'Mulliyawalai' (Mulliyawalai Centre, Mulliyawalai North/South/East/West). Their locations all seem to fall within the territory of the 18th-century 'Moellieawalle' province, as seen on maps of this period. The GeoNames ID of Mulliyawalai Centre is selected here.
[CONTEXT] GM 4:388 "[...] Allahabad, a city at 25°30' N. and 81°42' E."
[DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Akuressa. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the town of Akuressa and the fort of Akuressa.
[CONTEXT] GM 6:651 "Alwatirnagara, place at 9°35' N and 77°56' E."

[CONTEXT] According to the AMH, this place "was said to have been situated somewhere between Yala and Walawe on the south-eastern coast of Ceylon." Several 17th/18th-century maps of Sri Lanka confirm this location.
[DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Walawe. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the town of Walawe and the fort of Walawe.
[DISAMBIGUATION] This is a general entry for Tangalle. Under this entry, there are separate sub-entries for the town of Tangalle and the fort of Tangalle.

[CONTEX] GM 5:768 "The Alutkurukoralé extended southeast of Negombo." [COORD] [INFERENCE] The AMH coordinates of Negombo are used here as an inference for Alutkuru Korale, because a secondary source by Silva and Beumer indicates that Negombo was situated within Alutkuru Korale.
[CONTEXT] GM 1:131 "[...] the kingdom of Ahmadnagar, located north of Bijapur, under the Nizamshahs [...]."
